Genesis.author: Moses
Genesis.purpose: To record Elohiym's creation of the world and His desire to have a people set apart to worship Him
Genesis.overview: Genesis (meaning 'beginnings') chronicles creation, the fall of humanity, the flood, and the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Joseph. It establishes the covenant relationship between Elohiym and His chosen people.

Exodus.author: Moses
Exodus.purpose: To record Israel's deliverance from Egypt and the establishment of the covenant at Sinai
Exodus.overview: Exodus tells of Israel's slavery in Egypt, Moses' leadership, the plagues, the Passover, the Red Sea crossing, and the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai including the Tabernacle instructions.

Leviticus.author: Moses
Leviticus.purpose: To provide instructions for worship and living as Yahuah's holy people
Leviticus.overview: Leviticus details the sacrificial system, priesthood regulations, ceremonial laws, and holiness code. It emphasizes that Elohiym's people must be holy because He is holy.

Numbers.author: Moses
Numbers.purpose: To record Israel's wilderness wanderings and Elohiym's faithfulness despite their rebellion
Numbers.overview: Numbers chronicles Israel's journey from Sinai to the edge of the Promised Land, including census counts, rebellions, and the consequences of unbelief.

Deuteronomy.author: Moses
Deuteronomy.purpose: To remind the new generation of Elohiym's covenant and prepare them to enter Canaan
Deuteronomy.overview: Moses' farewell addresses restating the law, warning against idolatry, and calling Israel to love and obey Yahuah. Emphasizes the Shema and covenant renewal.

Joshua.author: Unknown (possibly Joshua)
Joshua.purpose: To demonstrate Yahuah's faithfulness in giving Israel the Promised Land
Joshua.overview: Under Joshua's leadership, Israel conquers Canaan, divides the land among the tribes, and renews their covenant with Yahuah at Shechem.

Judges.author: Unknown (possibly Samuel)
Judges.purpose: To show the consequences of Israel's unfaithfulness and the cycle of sin, judgment, and deliverance
Judges.overview: Chronicles the period between Joshua and Samuel when Israel repeatedly fell into idolatry and was delivered by judges whom Elohiym raised up.

Ruth.author: Unknown (possibly Samuel)
Ruth.purpose: To demonstrate Elohiym's providence and sovereign care through loyal love
Ruth.overview: The beautiful story of Ruth, a Moabite woman who shows covenant loyalty to her mother-in-law and becomes an ancestor of David and the Messiah.

1 Samuel.author: Unknown (possibly Samuel, Nathan, Gad)
1 Samuel.purpose: To record Israel's transition from judges to kingship under Samuel, Saul, and David
1 Samuel.overview: Chronicles Samuel's ministry, Saul's rise and fall, and David's anointing and rise to power, emphasizing that Yahuah seeks a heart fully devoted to Him.

2 Samuel.author: Unknown (possibly Nathan, Gad)
2 Samuel.purpose: To record David's reign as king and establish the Davidic covenant
2 Samuel.overview: David's successes and failures as king, including his sin with Bathsheba, and Elohiym's covenant promise of an eternal dynasty.

1 Kings.author: Unknown
1 Kings.purpose: To explain the division of Israel and Judah's decline through unfaithfulness
1 Kings.overview: Chronicles Solomon's reign, temple construction, the kingdom's division, and the ministries of Elijah and other prophets during a time of increasing idolatry.

2 Kings.author: Unknown
2 Kings.purpose: To record the exile of both kingdoms as judgment for persistent sin
2 Kings.overview: Continues the history of the divided kingdom, featuring Elisha's ministry, the fall of Israel to Assyria, and Judah's fall to Babylon.

1 Chronicles.author: Ezra (traditional)
1 Chronicles.purpose: To encourage post-exilic Israel by recounting Elohiym's faithfulness and the importance of proper worship
1 Chronicles.overview: Genealogies from Adam to David, David's reign with emphasis on preparations for the temple, establishing proper worship.

2 Chronicles.author: Ezra (traditional)
2 Chronicles.purpose: To emphasize Judah's spiritual history and the centrality of the temple
2 Chronicles.overview: Focuses on Judah's kings, temple history, and the nation's relationship with Yahuah, ending with Cyrus's decree to rebuild the temple.

Ezra.author: Ezra
Ezra.purpose: To record the return from exile and the rebuilding of the temple
Ezra.overview: Chronicles the first returns from Babylonian exile, temple reconstruction, and Ezra's reforms emphasizing separation from pagan practices and return to the Law.

Nehemiah.author: Nehemiah
Nehemiah.purpose: To record the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls and spiritual renewal
Nehemiah.overview: Nehemiah leads the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls despite opposition, followed by spiritual renewal through public reading of the Law and covenant renewal.

Esther.author: Unknown
Esther.purpose: To demonstrate Elohiym's providence in protecting His people
Esther.overview: The story of Esther, a Jewish queen in Persia, who risks her life to save her people from genocide, revealing Elohiym's hidden providence.

Job.author: Unknown
Job.purpose: To address the problem of innocent suffering and Elohiym's sovereignty
Job.overview: Job's story of extreme suffering, his dialogues with friends about suffering's meaning, and Elohiym's revelation of His wisdom and sovereignty.

Psalms.author: Multiple (David, Asaph, Sons of Korah, etc.)
Psalms.purpose: To provide a hymnal and prayer book for Israel's worship
Psalms.overview: A collection of 150 songs and prayers expressing praise, lament, thanksgiving, and wisdom. Central to Israel's worship and rich in Messianic prophecy.

Proverbs.author: Solomon (primarily)
Proverbs.purpose: To provide practical wisdom for godly living
Proverbs.overview: A collection of wise sayings and instructions emphasizing the fear of Yahuah as the beginning of wisdom and offering guidance for all areas of life.

Ecclesiastes.author: Solomon (traditional)
Ecclesiastes.purpose: To demonstrate the futility of life without Elohiym
Ecclesiastes.overview: Solomon's reflection on life's meaning, concluding that apart from fearing Elohiym and keeping His commandments, everything is meaningless.

Song of Solomon.author: Solomon (traditional)
Song of Solomon.purpose: To celebrate marital love as Elohiym's gift and picture His love for His people
Song of Solomon.overview: A poetic dialogue celebrating romantic love between bride and groom, often interpreted as picturing Messiah's love for His bride, the assembly.

Isaiah.author: Isaiah
Isaiah.purpose: To call Judah to faithfulness and proclaim both judgment and future restoration through Messiah
Isaiah.overview: Prophecies of judgment on Judah and nations, comfort for the exiles, and detailed Messianic prophecies including the Suffering Servant.

Jeremiah.author: Jeremiah
Jeremiah.purpose: To warn Judah of coming judgment and call for repentance
Jeremiah.overview: The 'weeping prophet' warns of Babylon's invasion, laments Judah's sin, and promises a new covenant and future restoration.

Lamentations.author: Jeremiah (traditional)
Lamentations.purpose: To mourn Jerusalem's destruction and affirm Yahuah's faithfulness despite judgment
Lamentations.overview: Five poetic laments over Jerusalem's fall, expressing deep grief while affirming Elohiym's steadfast love and sovereignty.

Ezekiel.author: Ezekiel
Ezekiel.purpose: To announce judgment on Jerusalem and promise future restoration
Ezekiel.overview: Visionary prophecies from exile in Babylon, including the valley of dry bones and the vision of a restored temple and renewed people.

Daniel.author: Daniel
Daniel.purpose: To encourage exiles with Elohiym's sovereignty over world kingdoms
Daniel.overview: Daniel and friends' faithfulness in Babylon, and prophetic visions of successive kingdoms and the coming eternal kingdom of Elohiym.

Hosea.author: Hosea
Hosea.purpose: To illustrate Elohiym's faithful love despite Israel's spiritual adultery
Hosea.overview: Hosea's marriage to unfaithful Gomer pictures Israel's unfaithfulness and Yahuah's persistent, covenant love and call to return.

Joel.author: Joel
Joel.purpose: To call for repentance and announce the Day of Yahuah
Joel.overview: A locust plague pictures coming judgment, followed by promises of restoration and the outpouring of the Ruach on all flesh.

Amos.author: Amos
Amos.purpose: To proclaim judgment on Israel for social injustice and empty religiosity
Amos.overview: The shepherd-prophet denounces Israel's oppression of the poor and warns of exile, while promising future restoration of David's fallen tent.

Obadiah.author: Obadiah
Obadiah.purpose: To announce judgment on Edom for violence against Judah
Obadiah.overview: The shortest Old Testament book pronounces judgment on Edom for pride and violence against Israel, promising Yahuah's kingdom will prevail.

Jonah.author: Jonah
Jonah.purpose: To demonstrate Elohiym's mercy extends even to Israel's enemies
Jonah.overview: Jonah's reluctant mission to Nineveh reveals Elohiym's compassion for all nations and challenges narrow nationalism and self-righteousness.

Micah.author: Micah
Micah.purpose: To denounce injustice and predict judgment, while promising a coming ruler from Bethlehem
Micah.overview: Alternates between pronouncements of judgment for sin and promises of restoration, including the famous Bethlehem prophecy of Messiah's birthplace.

Nahum.author: Nahum
Nahum.purpose: To announce Nineveh's destruction as judgment for cruelty
Nahum.overview: Proclaims judgment on Assyria's capital Nineveh for its violence, assuring Judah of Yahuah's justice and care for His people.

Habakkuk.author: Habakkuk
Habakkuk.purpose: To address the problem of evil and affirm that the righteous will live by faith
Habakkuk.overview: The prophet questions why Elohiym allows evil and will use wicked Babylon as His instrument, learning to trust in Yahuah's sovereign plan.

Zephaniah.author: Zephaniah
Zephaniah.purpose: To warn of the Day of Yahuah and call for humble seeking of Elohiym
Zephaniah.overview: Announces the coming Day of Yahuah with universal judgment, calling Judah to seek righteousness and promising future blessing for a remnant.

Haggai.author: Haggai
Haggai.purpose: To motivate the returned exiles to rebuild the temple
Haggai.overview: Calls the people to prioritize rebuilding Yahuah's house, promising His presence and blessing for obedience.

Zechariah.author: Zechariah
Zechariah.purpose: To encourage temple rebuilding and reveal future Messianic kingdom
Zechariah.overview: Eight night visions encourage temple rebuilding, followed by prophecies of Messiah's first and second comings and final restoration.

Malachi.author: Malachi
Malachi.purpose: To confront post-exilic spiritual apathy and promise the messenger who will prepare Messiah's way
Malachi.overview: The final Old Testament book rebukes priests and people for corruption while promising Elijah's return and the coming Day of Yahuah.

Matthew.author: Matthew
Matthew.purpose: To present Yahusha as the Messiah, King of the Jews, and fulfill Old Testament prophecy
Matthew.overview: Emphasizes Yahusha's fulfillment of Messianic prophecy, His teachings (including the Sermon on the Mount), and His rightful claim as Israel's King.

Mark.author: John Mark
Mark.purpose: To present Yahusha as the Suffering Servant who came to serve and give His life
Mark.overview: The shortest Gospel emphasizes Yahusha's actions and servanthood, moving rapidly through His ministry to His sacrificial death and resurrection.

Luke.author: Luke
Luke.purpose: To provide an orderly account of Yahusha's life for Gentile audiences
Luke.overview: The most comprehensive Gospel account, emphasizing Yahusha's humanity, compassion for outcasts, and prayer life. Companion to Acts.

John.author: John
John.purpose: To prove that Yahusha is the Son of Elohiym so that readers might believe and have life
John.overview: The theological Gospel emphasizes Yahusha's deity through seven signs and seven 'I AM' statements, culminating in His death and resurrection.

Acts.author: Luke
Acts.purpose: To record the birth and growth of the early assembly through the Holy Spirit's power
Acts.overview: Chronicles the Ruach's empowerment at Pentecost, the spread of the gospel from Jerusalem to Rome, and the ministries of Peter and Paul.

Romans.author: Paul
Romans.purpose: To present the gospel systematically: justification by faith and righteous living
Romans.overview: Paul's most systematic theological treatise explaining salvation, sanctification, and Israel's place in Elohiym's plan.

1 Corinthians.author: Paul
1 Corinthians.purpose: To address divisions and moral problems in the Corinthian assembly
1 Corinthians.overview: Corrects factionalism, sexual immorality, misuse of spiritual gifts, and confusion about resurrection while emphasizing love's supremacy.

2 Corinthians.author: Paul
2 Corinthians.purpose: To defend Paul's apostolic ministry and encourage generous giving
2 Corinthians.overview: Paul defends his ministry, describes the new covenant's glory, and encourages the Corinthians in generous giving and reconciliation.

Galatians.author: Paul
Galatians.purpose: To defend the gospel of grace against legalism
Galatians.overview: Paul's passionate defense of justification by faith alone, warning against adding works to grace and calling believers to walk in the Spirit.

Ephesians.author: Paul
Ephesians.purpose: To explain the mystery of the assembly and believers' identity in Messiah
Ephesians.overview: Describes the assembly's spiritual blessings, unity, and calling, with practical instructions for Spirit-filled living.

Philippians.author: Paul
Philippians.purpose: To express gratitude and encourage joy despite circumstances
Philippians.overview: Paul's joyful letter from prison encouraging humility, unity, and rejoicing, featuring the great Christ hymn.

Colossians.author: Paul
Colossians.purpose: To combat false teaching by affirming Messiah's supremacy
Colossians.overview: Exalts Yahusha's preeminence over all creation and philosophy, warning against legalism and encouraging godly living.

1 Thessalonians.author: Paul
1 Thessalonians.purpose: To encourage the young assembly and teach about Messiah's return
1 Thessalonians.overview: Paul commends the Thessalonians' faith, addresses concerns about deceased believers, and teaches about the Day of the Master.

2 Thessalonians.author: Paul
2 Thessalonians.purpose: To correct misunderstandings about the Day of the Master and encourage perseverance
2 Thessalonians.overview: Clarifies events preceding Messiah's return, encourages the persecuted believers, and addresses idleness in the assembly.

1 Timothy.author: Paul
1 Timothy.purpose: To instruct Timothy in pastoral leadership and combat false teaching
1 Timothy.overview: Paul's pastoral letter giving instructions for assembly leadership, qualifications for elders and deacons, and combating false doctrine.

2 Timothy.author: Paul
2 Timothy.purpose: To encourage Timothy to remain faithful and continue Paul's work
2 Timothy.overview: Paul's final letter urging Timothy to guard the gospel, endure suffering, and preach the Word faithfully.

Titus.author: Paul
Titus.purpose: To guide Titus in establishing leadership and promoting sound doctrine in Crete
Titus.overview: Instructions for appointing elders, combating false teaching, and living out the gospel in good works.

Philemon.author: Paul
Philemon.purpose: To appeal for forgiveness and reconciliation for Onesimus, a runaway slave
Philemon.overview: A personal letter demonstrating Christian brotherhood, forgiveness, and the transforming power of the gospel in relationships.

Hebrews.author: Unknown
Hebrews.purpose: To demonstrate Messiah's superiority and encourage perseverance in faith
Hebrews.overview: Shows Yahusha's supremacy over angels, Moses, and the Levitical priesthood, warning against apostasy and encouraging faithful endurance.

James.author: James (Jesus' brother)
James.purpose: To call believers to genuine faith demonstrated by works
James.overview: Practical wisdom on living out faith through trials, taming the tongue, caring for the poor, and patient endurance.

1 Peter.author: Peter
1 Peter.purpose: To encourage suffering believers to remain faithful as strangers and exiles
1 Peter.overview: Encourages persecuted believers with their living hope, calling them to holy living and faithful witness amid suffering.

2 Peter.author: Peter
2 Peter.purpose: To warn against false teachers and encourage growth in grace
2 Peter.overview: Peter's final letter warning against false teachers, defending the certainty of Messiah's return, and encouraging spiritual growth.

1 John.author: John
1 John.purpose: To combat false teaching and assure believers of eternal life
1 John.overview: Tests of genuine faith: believing in Yahusha, loving others, and obeying Elohiym's commands. Emphasizes that Elohiym is love.

2 John.author: John
2 John.purpose: To warn against welcoming false teachers who deny Messiah's incarnation
2 John.overview: A brief letter emphasizing love and truth while warning against showing hospitality to those who deny Messiah.

3 John.author: John
3 John.purpose: To commend Gaius's hospitality and rebuke Diotrephes's prideful leadership
3 John.overview: Personal encouragement to Gaius for supporting traveling teachers, contrasted with Diotrephes's selfish behavior.

Jude.author: Jude (Jesus' brother)
Jude.purpose: To warn against false teachers and call believers to contend for the faith
Jude.overview: Urgent warning against false teachers who deny Master Yahusha, calling believers to remain faithful and build themselves up in the faith.

Revelation.author: John
Revelation.purpose: To reveal Messiah's glory and assure believers of His ultimate victory
Revelation.overview: Apocalyptic visions of Messiah's glory, judgment on evil, and the establishment of the new heaven and earth where Elohiym dwells with His people.
